qas.question: How long has copper been in use?
What percentage of copper has been extracted since 1900?
How much of mined cooper has been extracted in the last 24 years?
How much copper is estimated to exsist on earth?
What is a major source of cooper in modern times?
How long has copper been forbidden?
What percentage of copper has been stolen since 1900?
How much of mined cooper has been extracted in the last 24 hours?
How much copper is estimated to be missing on earth?
What is a minor source of cooper in modern times?

context: Copper has been in use <a0_0><b5_0>at least 10,000 years<b5_0/><a0_0/>, but more than <a1_0><b6_0>95%<b6_0/><a1_0/> of all copper ever mined and smelted has been extracted since 1900, and <a2_0><b7_0>more than half<b7_0/><a2_0/> was extracted in only the last 24 years. As with many natural resources, the total amount of copper on Earth is vast (around <a3_0><b8_0>1014 tons<b8_0/><a3_0/> just in the top kilometer of Earth's crust, or about 5 million years' worth at the current rate of extraction). However, only a tiny fraction of these reserves is economically viable, given present-day prices and technologies. Various estimates of existing copper reserves available for mining vary from 25 years to 60 years, depending on core assumptions such as the growth rate. <a4_0><b9_0>Recycling<b9_0/><a4_0/> is a major source of copper in the modern world. Because of these and other factors, the future of copper production and supply is the subject of much debate, including the concept of peak copper, analogous to peak oil.
